comments.commentBody:
Joseph - I don't understand why it's not clear to people that PK's disagreement with Sanders is not about goals. It's about methods and strategy. PK thinks Sanders doesn't know from nuttin' about how to reach - or even takee the next several steps toward - the goals they share. PK also asserts that the specifics Sanders proposed undermine the process. He's very specific about why he thinks Sanders doesn't know what he's doing.

It has *nothing* to do with goals.

LeBron James is Superman.

Congratulations to the Calaviers and Cleveland, Ohio !
Congrats to Cleveland for this hard-fought win.  It was a long time coming.
How can they be world champions if the rest of the world wasn't playing?

you need to be a gracious losers. just say congratulations and go away.

— lincoln west high class of '77, cleveland
They lost to men.
And you sir, need to be a gracious winner.  It seems Kasia was being gracious.
So sad. Wish our boys had won.

I joked with a friend from Cleveland on Friday if she would be there during the championship's parade for the cavs ? She was confused and asked to explained what I meant ? A hope I said, it's a hope.
And here it is, well deserved cavs. Congrats !
If anyone ever deserved it, it's LeBron. Amazing athlete, excellent human being.

James, my friend,

For the first time you showed all you are made of the right stuff. You made it happen You deserve it all.

I, among many, Love You...
Indeed, jazz on the b-ball court. The word improvisation really does encapsulate this performance by the Cavs.  Great, historic game for the ages.

It was a lot more than robotics that one him a unanimous MVP but hats off to the Lebron and Co. for a great stretch of games.

With a healthy Curry, we'll get 'em next year.

This was great basketball. Draymond Green had an amazing first half. But the game is 48 minutes long and, like in games 5 & 6, you could see the Warriors flag late. Curry is a great shooter but also one dimensional. James brings everything to the table: points, assists, blocks, and rebounds. Kyrie Irving is a threat from everywhere on the floor, a genius of improvisation to Curry's robotics. Great teams win in the paint - and in the paint it wasn't even close.
Power of one man's determination ably aided by few teammates along, showed anything is possible. We were all witness to that. Great show.

I kinda like the idea of basketball as a game capable of being won by ordinary mortals with superb, well-honed skills. What is it you find more exciting about a game that can only be won by physical freaks of nature and pituitary giants?
All the better because Kyrie hits the winning 3 in Curry's face.  Meanwhile, Curry is bricking at the 3 on the other end...
LeBron has not only won his team the first NBA championship title but also saved the basketball from being degraded into a 3 point contest.
Well, a little more than just talk.
That talk is when I switched off on the Warriors. The last thing we need is to hear more about tech.
Good.  At long last.  All that talk about the Warriors being technology's team, being proof of the transcedental power of Silicon Valley, is just that:  talk.  Congratulations, Cavs.

I actually DID yell it out & my DH had no idea what I was talking about!

That battle scene was incredibly challenging to watch, and I could really feel Jon's suffocation. Sadly I was thinking serves you right for being STUPID in your battle "plan". I agree with another commenter that if a woman does not end up on the throne of the 7 kingdoms then the glass ceiling is obviously much thicker than anything we encounter today. Go girl power go!
I was saying EXACTLY the same thing!
This was the best reference I've seen, lol!!
Did anyone else have the urge to yell "Serpentine, Rickon, serpentine!" ??

comments.userLocation: Somewhere on the Appalachian Trail, with days off to watch Game of Thrones
comments.commentBody: Lucky Dog, you keep saying stepbrother. It's half brother. Ramsey and the infant shared the same father.
That was the best dialogue moment of the hour, methinks!
Nope, he was right.  The dogs ate Fat Walda and the baby in Winterfell.

Sisters are certainly doing it for themselves on GoT - and Jon Snow still knows nothing. Ramsay's psychological digs - calling Jon names, and killing Rickon to egg Snow into the very trap on the battlefield that Sansa predicted  - lasted to the very end. His taunts to Sansa, even as he sat bloodied in the very place that he killed his stepmother and newborn stepbrother via dogs - ugh. But this episode also featured the loss of yet another beloved follower - we recently suffered the loss of Hodor, protecting Bran. This week, Dundun was done, helping Jon. We will miss Dundun. The battle scenes were horrific and hard to watch, but beautifully directed and filmed - now we know why the last 3 episodes were dull, and a lot of deaths were offscreen - the Waif and Blackfish - to save the budget for this week's epic battle. Truly frightening, it reminded me of the opening 20 minutes of Saving Private Ryan - you did not want to watch, but could not turn away. Well done, GoT cast and crew.

I especially loved how you could see Drogon materialize far in the distance behind the Masters as they were so arrogantly taunting Dany, and you see him almost lazily flapping his wings, bringing the slaver's their doom, as they remain unaware (for a few seconds at least).  Fabulous!
Brilliant, tense, bloody and satisfying, terrifically directed and acted, the  best drame on  television.  Drogon definitly deserves an special Emmy.
I agree.  Burns with King's Landing, Havisham-style.

Cersai will be stabbed in the back by Jaime after she reveals her plan to use wild fire on Kings Landing. Briennes admiration of Jaimes honor will lead him to decide to kill Cersai as he did the Mad King- to save innocents.

This may be a stupid question Zorrah, let me preface by saying I really like Jaimie's character, but didn't he kill Arys because Tywin said? That being said Cersei was hated, and she was a b to some people, but still, all of her machinations usually fall flat or end up hurting her long term game or others. (I.E faith militant). I doubt Walder Frey could be THE bad guy, and like some have said about the Ice king, he is AN evil, but not evil, he isn't flaying, sending young girls to marry dwarves, or cross bowing prostitutes. I think the FM would be the worst we have for a little bit, i don't know much about Euron. While it is good to have a person we hate... an evil man, we know Petyr has a very shady side and has someone said chooses to be evil. But with Varys coming back, we know there is someone besides Sansa who knows Petyr isn't the man he plays himself to be.

Now that Ramsay Bolton is gone, whom will we direct our animus at? Throughout the history of the show, it's always had a truly awful, mythically sadistic villain to hold our attention. I see no one on the show now that fills that role. And to quibble on a plot point, why would the Masters launch an attack on Mereen without first being 100 percent sure that the dragons were either dead or in some way out of pocket?
But the battle scene between Winterfell and Jon's rag tag bunch was brilliant, almost as good as the Hardhome fight. And we finally got to see Davos learn what's happened to Shereen.
But...which major character will die on next week's season finale? Every season has seen a pivotal character die. Didn't see Arya in the preview -- did I miss it? Is that a clue?Or will Sansa get it right after she's grown to something more than just being a perpetual victim.

"I wish, however, the show did not continue to indicate that all is but a long prelude to a dragons vs. White Walkers showdown, with the dragons seeming invincible."

Yup.

Very good point, however I was so moved by Jon racing for Recon.. It was powerful. The Jon I know, could not sit there no matter what and watch his brother just run, even if Jon was told before hand that that exact thing would happen. :) Yes, oddly Ramsey gave this show a LOT of dimension. And even if we hated him, he still gave us something to react to.
Haven't we had to suspend disbelief at Sansa's transformation?  Wasn't it just 2 seasons ago that she was giddy about a tournament/pageant? At least Jon has been more consistent to his character.

A very exciting and satisfying episode, well summarized.

Fine acting by Yara (one of the most charismatic characters in the show, and a reminder that women need not be beautiful and naked to catch male viewers' interest) and Theon.

I wish, however, the show did not continue to indicate that all is but a long prelude to a dragons vs. White Walkers showdown, with the dragons seeming invincible.

Worst prediction of the show, other than by Bolton: Jon Snow saying Bolton's men would turn on him for not fighting for them or when things went poorly (or, as it turned out, when he was wiling to kill many of them in a rain of arrows).

Anyone else who was disappointed that Jon proved a poor tactician bailed out by Littlefinger? Seeing Bolton pounded and eaten was fine, but I wish we had seen the arrogant twerp outsmarted first by Jon.

Definitely, the kids are taking over, and the world will be better for it. The patriarchs of most major houses are gone, the closest we've got to elder statesman now are Kevan and creepy uncle Littlefinger.

From the look on the face of Jamie in the preview, I'm not sure Walder Frey will be long for this world.

"the kids are taking over, and the world will be better for it." That's what they say, but I wouldn't be money on it, though we may never know, except in the movies, should they decide to generate a gazillion dollars in box office revenues.
So fitting that the show was broadcast on Father's Day, in light of the remarks by Dany, Yara, Tyrion, and Theon!
Margaery is her grandmother's granddaughter - she has something up her sleeve, for sure.

Yup the women in this show are awesome and always have been really. The people who try to call this show or GRRM sexist/misogynistic have small minds in my opinion or just lack attention spans.

~ I don't mean to come off as rude to anyone but that is just my opinion.
And young Lyanna Mormont deserves mention in the group of rising women characters. I hope we see more of her.

This was a great episode, definitely the best since Hardhome. Orchestrating two major battle scenes in the span of an hour takes quite a bit of directorial skill. The aerial scenes from the dragons-eye view in Meereen were stunning. The battle for Winterfell reminded me quite a bit of Lord of the Rings, but in a good way. The claustrophobic scene of Jon being trampled and buried was particularly well done. Littlefinger's arrival with his army wasn't exactly a surprise, but it was welcome, so no complaints from me.

It was good to see Sansa finally take her revenge on Ramsay. I think most people had correctly guessed how Ramsay would meet his demise, but it was satisfying nonetheless. RIP Wun Win. Not a good season for the big guys.

For me, this episode completed the transition of the women from abused and powerless characters early on to strong and dominant players now. Between Dany, Yara, Sansa, the Martell women in Dorne, and Margaery Tyrell (who I suspect is plotting behind the scenes in King's Landing), the women are now truly running the show. The fact that this change feels believable is a credit to the storytelling in this series.

Tyrion is the power and wisdom behind Daenerys' throne. Let us not be too hasty with praises for the dragon queen. She was quite clueless, but with the help and advice of Jorah and Ser Barriston she has survived. So far as I can see, all her three mentors have been men!

Regarding Sansa--I was wondering if she wasn't sure that the Vale would show up. We saw her send the letter, but we never saw a response. Maybe she didn't want to get Jon's hopes up if they weren't coming?

For me, Tyrion is still a Lannister. We (most of us) love him; but his endgame is unclear. I'm not convinced that he truly thinks Danaerys is really all that great or the best choice to rule Westeros.

I could well see Tyrion sitting on the Iron Throne when all is said and done.

Queen's Landing. Nice touch!
Sansa did her best to warn Jon to not do what Ramsay wanted. But Jon fell for Ramsay's manipulation and nearly had his side destroyed. His plan for a pincer failed and it was Ramsay who used a pincer. However, let's not rush to laud Sansa just yet. If she had told Jon about the Arryn army beforehand, the Stark army could have waited another day and a lot of wildling/Mormonts/other northern lives would have been spared. Here's hoping that both Starks have learned the lesson of listening and trusting the other. They'll need a united front against the master manipulator, Littlefinger (though I'm hoping Bran shows up early in season 7 to poke big holes in Littlefinger's stories, especially the ones Sansa doesn't know).
As gratifying as Ramsay's death was, the comeuppance of the 3 masters was also quite good from Dany's line about the day her reign began to Grey worm's quick execution. I think the days of men underestimating her are officially OVER.
Yes

Congratulations to the Cavaliers, their fans and the people of Cleveland. It is thrilling to see a long-deferred dream realized.

And to defeat a superb team like the Warriors no doubt makes victory all the sweeter.

When I lived in Honolulu thirty years ago, I called a local radio station at 3 am to make a request. I asked them to play a Juice Newton song. The guy responded with "we play rock and roll."

And that's my Juice Newton story.

.
A teenaged MTF was taken to a Juice Newton show at a club whose name has receded in memory. It was in Manhattan though.

It was a perfectly nice show. Some of the 1960s rock acts that play shows after becoming eligible for Social Security don't rock as hard as Juice did. Which isn't to say that she rocked particularly hard.

Well, the puzzle offered a clever and timely theme, but it was way too easy, even for a Monday. It felt more appropriate for a weekly supermarket flyer than for the New York Times.

By the way, Deb, I think you maybe dropped the ball in omitting Juice from the list of possible Newtons. She was a very successful pop and then country singer in the late '70s and the '80s.

Nah, season 5 was far weaker. That whole season was setups with no payoffs leaving cliffhangers for episode 10. This season has lots of payoffs and episode 9 is the king or perhaps I should say queen of these.

I was more engaged w/ S5. Felt the dialog was much better, the tangents less dull. But it was def the weakest until this one. At least until this amazing ninth episode, that is. Thanks for your civil response!
Weakest season unexpectedly delivers best episode of series. Bravo.
